questions.question: Sound is produced by:
questions.explanation: Sound is produced by vibrating bodies. When an object vibrates, it creates disturbances in the surrounding medium that travel as sound waves.

questions.question: The to and fro motion of an object about its mean position is called:
questions.explanation: Vibratory motion (or oscillatory motion) is the to and fro motion of an object about its mean position.

questions.question: In a tuning fork, sound is produced by the vibration of:
questions.explanation: When a tuning fork is struck, its prongs (also called tines) vibrate and produce sound.

questions.question: The voice box in humans is called:
questions.explanation: The larynx, also known as the voice box, is located at the top of the windpipe and contains the vocal cords that produce sound.

questions.question: In humans, sound is produced by the vibration of:
questions.explanation: The vocal cords in the larynx vibrate when air from the lungs passes through them, producing sound.

questions.question: Which of the following is a stringed musical instrument?
questions.explanation: Sitar is a stringed instrument where sound is produced by the vibration of strings.

questions.question: In a drum, sound is produced by the vibration of:
questions.explanation: In drums (percussion instruments), sound is produced by the vibration of the stretched membrane when struck.

questions.question: In a flute, sound is produced by the vibration of:
questions.explanation: In wind instruments like the flute, sound is produced by the vibration of the air column inside the instrument.

questions.question: Sound waves are:
questions.explanation: Sound waves are longitudinal waves where particles of the medium vibrate parallel to the direction of wave propagation.

questions.question: Sound cannot travel through:
questions.explanation: Sound requires a material medium to travel. It cannot travel through vacuum as there are no particles to vibrate.

questions.question: The region of high pressure in a sound wave is called:
questions.explanation: In a sound wave, compression is the region where particles are crowded together, creating high pressure.

questions.question: The region of low pressure in a sound wave is called:
questions.explanation: In a sound wave, rarefaction is the region where particles are spread apart, creating low pressure.

questions.question: One complete to and fro motion of a vibrating body is called:
questions.explanation: One complete to and fro motion (one complete vibration) is called an oscillation.

questions.question: The number of oscillations per second is called:
questions.explanation: Frequency is the number of oscillations (or vibrations) completed per second.

questions.question: The SI unit of frequency is:
questions.explanation: The SI unit of frequency is Hertz (Hz), named after Heinrich Hertz. 1 Hz = 1 oscillation per second.

questions.question: The time taken for one complete oscillation is called:
questions.explanation: Time period (T) is the time taken for one complete oscillation or vibration.

questions.question: The maximum displacement of a vibrating body from its mean position is called:
questions.explanation: Amplitude is the maximum displacement of a vibrating body from its mean (rest) position.

questions.question: The distance covered by a wave in one complete oscillation is called:
questions.explanation: Wavelength is the distance between two consecutive compressions or rarefactions (one complete wave).

questions.question: The relationship between frequency (f) and time period (T) is:
questions.explanation: Frequency and time period are reciprocals of each other. f = 1/T or T = 1/f.

questions.question: The speed of sound is given by the formula:
questions.explanation: The speed of sound (v) equals frequency (f) multiplied by wavelength (λ). v = f × λ

questions.question: The speed of sound in air at room temperature is approximately:
questions.explanation: The speed of sound in air at room temperature (about 20°C) is approximately 340 m/s.

questions.question: Sound travels fastest in:
questions.explanation: Sound travels fastest in solids because particles are closely packed and can transmit vibrations quickly.

questions.question: Sound travels slowest in:
questions.explanation: Sound travels slowest in gases because particles are far apart and take longer to transmit vibrations.

questions.question: The loudness of sound depends on:
questions.explanation: Loudness depends on amplitude. Greater amplitude means louder sound.

questions.question: The pitch of sound depends on:
questions.explanation: Pitch depends on frequency. Higher frequency means higher pitch (shriller sound).

questions.question: A sound with high frequency is said to have:
questions.explanation: High frequency corresponds to high pitch. For example, a whistle has high pitch due to high frequency.

questions.question: The quality of sound that distinguishes between two sounds of same pitch and loudness is called:
questions.explanation: Timbre (or quality) allows us to distinguish between different sources producing sounds of same pitch and loudness.

questions.question: The range of human hearing is:
questions.explanation: Humans can hear sounds in the frequency range of 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz (20 kHz).

questions.question: Sounds with frequency above 20,000 Hz are called:
questions.explanation: Ultrasonic sounds have frequencies above 20,000 Hz, beyond the upper limit of human hearing.

questions.question: Sounds with frequency below 20 Hz are called:
questions.explanation: Infrasonic sounds have frequencies below 20 Hz, below the lower limit of human hearing.

questions.question: Which animal can produce ultrasonic sounds?
questions.explanation: Bats produce ultrasonic sounds (above 20,000 Hz) for navigation using echolocation.

questions.question: Which animal can produce infrasonic sounds?
questions.explanation: Elephants produce infrasonic sounds (below 20 Hz) to communicate over long distances.

questions.question: The reflection of sound is called:
questions.explanation: When sound bounces back from a surface and is heard again, it is called an echo.

questions.question: For an echo to be heard, the minimum distance of the reflecting surface should be:
questions.explanation: For an echo to be heard distinctly, the reflecting surface must be at least 17 metres away.

questions.question: The minimum time gap between original sound and echo for them to be heard separately is:
questions.explanation: Human ear can distinguish two sounds only if they reach the ear with a gap of at least 0.1 seconds (persistence of hearing).

questions.question: SONAR stands for:
questions.explanation: SONAR stands for Sound Navigation and Ranging. It uses ultrasonic waves to detect objects underwater.

questions.question: SONAR uses which type of waves?
questions.explanation: SONAR uses ultrasonic waves to detect underwater objects, measure depth, and locate fish shoals.

questions.question: Ultrasound is used in medicine for:
questions.explanation: Ultrasound scanning (sonography) is used to view internal organs and monitor pregnancy without harmful radiation.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a use of ultrasound?
questions.explanation: X-ray imaging uses electromagnetic radiation, not ultrasound. Ultrasound is used for cleaning, breaking kidney stones, and detecting flaws.

questions.question: The unit of loudness is:
questions.explanation: Loudness is measured in decibels (dB). The decibel scale is logarithmic.

questions.question: The symbol for wavelength is:
questions.explanation: Wavelength is represented by the Greek letter lambda (λ).

questions.question: Which characteristic of sound helps us identify the voice of a person?
questions.explanation: Quality or timbre helps us identify different voices even when they have the same pitch and loudness.

questions.question: The vibration of a simple pendulum is an example of:
questions.explanation: A simple pendulum exhibits oscillatory (vibratory) motion as it swings to and fro about its mean position.

questions.question: In which medium does sound travel faster - iron or water?
questions.explanation: Sound travels faster in iron (a solid) than in water (a liquid) because particles in solids are more closely packed.

questions.question: The speed of sound in water is approximately:
questions.explanation: The speed of sound in water is approximately 1500 m/s, which is about 4.4 times faster than in air.

questions.question: If frequency of a sound is doubled, its pitch:
questions.explanation: Pitch is directly proportional to frequency. Doubling frequency doubles the pitch (makes it shriller).

questions.question: If amplitude of a sound is doubled, its loudness:
questions.explanation: Loudness increases with amplitude. Greater amplitude means louder sound.

questions.question: Which part of the ear vibrates when sound enters?
questions.explanation: When sound enters the ear, it causes the eardrum (tympanic membrane) to vibrate.

questions.question: Sound waves carry:
questions.explanation: Sound waves transfer energy from one place to another without transferring matter.

questions.question: The voice of a child is shriller than an adult because:
options: B. Child's vocal cords are shorter
C. Child's vocal cords are longer
questions.correct_answer: B. Child's vocal cords are shorter
questions.explanation: Shorter vocal cords vibrate faster, producing higher frequency sound (shriller voice).

questions.question: The voice of men is generally deeper than women because:
options: B. Men's vocal cords are shorter
C. Men's vocal cords are longer and thicker
questions.correct_answer: C. Men's vocal cords are longer and thicker
questions.explanation: Longer and thicker vocal cords vibrate slower, producing lower frequency sound (deeper voice).

questions.question: Dolphins use ultrasound for:
questions.explanation: Dolphins produce ultrasonic sounds for echolocation to navigate and locate prey underwater.

questions.question: Which of the following produces sound by vibration of reed?
questions.explanation: In harmonium and other reed instruments, sound is produced by the vibration of thin metal strips called reeds.

questions.question: Noise pollution can cause:
questions.explanation: Noise pollution can cause hearing loss, stress, sleep disturbance, and other health problems.

questions.question: Sound level above how many decibels can cause hearing damage?
questions.explanation: Prolonged exposure to sounds above 80 dB can cause hearing damage. Safe limit is usually considered around 70-80 dB.

questions.question: Normal conversation has a sound level of approximately:
questions.explanation: Normal conversation is typically at 40-60 decibels, which is a comfortable hearing level.

questions.question: Which instrument is used to measure the intensity of sound?
questions.explanation: A sound level meter (decibel meter) is used to measure the intensity of sound in decibels.

questions.question: In a longitudinal wave, particles of the medium move:
questions.explanation: In longitudinal waves like sound, particles vibrate parallel (back and forth) to the direction of wave propagation.

questions.question: The speed of sound increases with:
questions.explanation: Speed of sound increases with temperature because molecules move faster at higher temperatures.

questions.question: Why can we not hear sound on the moon?
options: B. There is no air (vacuum) on moon
questions.correct_answer: B. There is no air (vacuum) on moon
questions.explanation: Sound cannot travel through vacuum. Since moon has no atmosphere, sound cannot be heard there.

questions.question: Thunder is heard after lightning is seen because:
options: B. Sound travels slower than light
C. Light travels slower than sound
D. Our eyes are faster than ears
questions.correct_answer: B. Sound travels slower than light
questions.explanation: Light travels at 3 × 10^8 m/s while sound travels at only 340 m/s. So we see lightning before hearing thunder.

questions.question: Multiple reflections of sound are called:
questions.explanation: When sound reflects multiple times in an enclosed space before dying out, it is called reverberation.

questions.question: To reduce reverberation in halls and auditoriums, walls are covered with:
questions.explanation: Sound absorbing materials like curtains, carpets, and acoustic panels reduce reflection and reverberation.

questions.question: Stethoscope works on the principle of:
questions.explanation: In a stethoscope, sound is reflected multiple times through the tube to reach the doctor's ears.

questions.question: Megaphone and loudspeaker work on the principle of:
questions.explanation: Megaphones use multiple reflections to direct sound in a particular direction, increasing its loudness.

questions.question: The phenomenon used by bats to navigate is called:
questions.explanation: Bats use echolocation - they emit ultrasonic sounds and detect objects from the reflected echoes.

questions.question: If the frequency of a wave is 100 Hz, its time period is:
questions.explanation: Time period T = 1/f = 1/100 = 0.01 seconds.

questions.question: If the time period of a wave is 0.05 seconds, its frequency is:
questions.explanation: Frequency f = 1/T = 1/0.05 = 20 Hz.

questions.question: A sound wave has frequency 200 Hz and wavelength 1.7 m. Its speed is:
Which of the following has the highest frequency?
questions.explanation: Ultrasonic sounds have frequency above 20,000 Hz, which is higher than audible (20-20,000 Hz) and infrasonic (<20 Hz).

questions.question: The wavelength of audible sound ranges from:
questions.explanation: Using v = f × λ and v = 340 m/s: for 20 Hz, λ = 17 m; for 20,000 Hz, λ = 17 mm.

questions.question: Which property of sound helps in determining the distance of an obstacle?
questions.explanation: By measuring the time for an echo to return, we can calculate the distance to an obstacle.

questions.question: Earthquakes produce which type of sound waves?
questions.explanation: Earthquakes produce infrasonic waves (below 20 Hz) that can travel long distances.

questions.question: The sound of frequency 50 Hz can be heard by:
questions.explanation: 50 Hz is within the audible range (20-20,000 Hz) for humans and many animals.

questions.question: The sound of frequency 50,000 Hz can be heard by:
questions.explanation: 50,000 Hz is ultrasonic (above 20,000 Hz), which cannot be heard by humans but can be heard by bats and dolphins.

questions.question: Which animal can detect earthquakes before they occur?
questions.explanation: Elephants can detect infrasonic vibrations produced before earthquakes, helping them sense danger early.

questions.question: In a guitar, shorter strings produce:
questions.explanation: Shorter strings vibrate faster, producing higher frequency and higher pitch sounds.

questions.question: Tightening a string in a guitar makes the pitch:
questions.explanation: Tighter strings vibrate faster, increasing frequency and thus increasing pitch.

questions.question: Which of the following is a percussion instrument?
questions.explanation: Tabla is a percussion instrument where sound is produced by striking a stretched membrane.

questions.question: The medical technique using ultrasound to break kidney stones is called:
questions.explanation: Lithotripsy uses high-intensity ultrasound waves to break kidney stones into smaller pieces.

questions.question: Ultrasound can detect cracks in metal because:
options: B. It reflects from crack surfaces
questions.correct_answer: B. It reflects from crack surfaces
questions.explanation: Ultrasound waves reflect from internal cracks or flaws, helping detect defects in metal structures.

questions.question: The frequency of ultrasound used in medical scanning is typically:
questions.explanation: Medical ultrasound typically uses frequencies in the megahertz range (1-15 MHz) for good image resolution.

questions.question: Persistence of hearing in human ear is about:
questions.explanation: Human ear retains sensation of sound for about 0.1 seconds (persistence of hearing).

questions.question: Sound waves are also called:
questions.explanation: Sound waves are mechanical waves because they require a material medium to propagate.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about sound waves?
options: A. They can travel through vacuum
questions.explanation: Sound waves are longitudinal waves that require a medium and cannot travel through vacuum.

questions.question: The distance between two consecutive compressions is equal to:
questions.explanation: The distance between two consecutive compressions (or rarefactions) equals one wavelength.

questions.question: Density of medium is maximum at:
questions.explanation: At compression, particles are crowded together, making the density maximum.

questions.question: Pressure is minimum at:
questions.explanation: At rarefaction, particles are spread apart, making the pressure minimum.

questions.question: A mosquito produces sound of approximately which frequency?
questions.explanation: A mosquito's buzz is typically in the range of 200-500 Hz, which is audible to humans.

questions.question: A dog whistle produces sound of frequency:
questions.explanation: Dog whistles produce ultrasonic sounds (above 20,000 Hz) that dogs can hear but humans cannot.

questions.question: If you see a person hammering from far away, you hear the sound:
options: A. Before seeing the hammer strike
B. Exactly when the hammer strikes
C. After seeing the hammer strike
questions.correct_answer: C. After seeing the hammer strike
questions.explanation: Light travels much faster than sound, so we see the action before hearing the sound.

questions.question: The speed of sound in steel is approximately:
questions.explanation: Sound travels at about 5000 m/s in steel, much faster than in air or water.

questions.question: Which of the following affects the speed of sound in air?
questions.explanation: Temperature affects the speed of sound. Higher temperature means faster molecular motion and higher speed of sound.

questions.question: Sound absorbing materials are used on walls to:
questions.explanation: Sound absorbing materials reduce reflection, preventing unwanted echo and reverberation.

questions.question: In an ultrasound scan during pregnancy, we can see:
options: B. Image of baby using sound reflections
questions.correct_answer: B. Image of baby using sound reflections
questions.explanation: Ultrasound scanning creates images from sound wave reflections, safely viewing the baby without radiation.

questions.question: What happens to the wavelength when frequency increases (at constant speed)?
questions.explanation: Since v = f × λ, if v is constant and f increases, λ must decrease.

questions.question: Which of the following sounds has the longest wavelength?
questions.explanation: Lower frequency sounds (like bass drum) have longer wavelengths. λ = v/f, so lower f means higher λ.

questions.question: Veena, sitar, and guitar are all examples of:
questions.explanation: Veena, sitar, and guitar all produce sound through vibrating strings.

questions.question: The ceiling of concert halls is curved to:
options: B. Direct sound uniformly to audience
questions.correct_answer: B. Direct sound uniformly to audience
questions.explanation: Curved ceilings use sound reflection to direct and distribute sound evenly across the audience.

questions.question: If an echo is heard 4 seconds after the original sound and speed of sound is 340 m/s, the distance to the reflecting surface is:
questions.explanation: Total distance traveled = 340 × 4 = 1360 m. Since sound travels to the surface and back, distance = 1360/2 = 680 m.
